answers.answer: 1. It depends on what kind of seizures you're having. If they are grand mal or generalized seizures in which you completely lose consciousness, then antiepileptic treatment should be more aggressive. Otherwise, you'll have to discuss this with your neurologist as to how aggressive you want to be. It would be ideal to be completely seizure free, but as you had/have a structural lesion (tumor) and now surgical scar - both can serve as a chronic irritant for seizures.2.no3.it's always better to be on the least amount of medications possible. I suspect that once the lamictal starts kicking in, the phenobarb will be taken away.  Then you'd only be on two drugs, which is fine (3 is ok too if you need it, but the risk of side effects go up with amount of meds). Keppra is relatively safe with few side effects and no significant drug interactions.Best of luck.
